content:
2
												Nice story and character moments, and the visuals hold up surprisingly well. Aside from modding potential, this release has 2 specific advantages to simply emulating the original, getting in on PSN, etc.1) Hi-speed mode. This is like unlocking the FPS limit on an emulator, but the music doesn't get warped. Since you will spend a lot of time either in the field or an unskippable cutscene, this could save you multiple hours in a single playthrough. Also, during certain timed segments the timer will not be sped up - this is kinda cheating, but arguably justified since you're dealing with some annoyingly long battle animations. I think you can use this hotkey (F1), avoid the rest (F2-F5, which are unquestionably cheating) and still feel like you are playing legitimately.2) Magic Booster. This is a built-in hack that gives you 100 copies of every spell in your inventory, for each character. But it does not give you spells you don't have. This is definitely cheating, but if you've played the game before, you might see this cheat as acceptable compared to max Gil/damage/etc... you can easily farm 100 copies of most spells, but it is very time-consuming.That said, this game has some design issues regardless of what platform you're on. The Junction system is kinda broken, and the game ends up becoming very easy once you've obtained enough spells (which takes time and/or effort, but not skill). For me, one particular character could completely demolish every boss with little to no strategy involved. It's not awful, but it's not great either, which is why I think stuff like the magic booster isn't a big deal. Overall, this is one you'll enjoy for the story over the gameplay.

content:
r 8, 2014
Short version: 90%Final Fantasy VIII was the point where the series reached a whole new level, thanks to small changes like the focus on the romantic story elements and the more realistic character design. The Steam edition includes a few additional features over the old PC release, making it one of the best ports of the game so far, recommended for old fans or newcomers who would like to experience one of the gems of the golden age of Final Fantasy.Long version:Final Fantasy VIII was sort of a trailblazer when it came out. This was the first Final Fantasy game where we said goodbye to the traditional NES/SNES era cartoonish characters in favour of a more realistic design, and where the romance plot-- which is normally a secondary or tertiary storyline in similar games-- is promoted to be in the focus.This won’t turn FFVIII into a romance/dating game, far from it: your main task is still to save the world/universe from the ridiculous-haired main villain. To do so you’ll have to gather friends and allies, explore much of the planet, and of course slowly discover a rich backstory told in two separate timelines, which will eventually (with a little guess work) uncover one of the most confusing, yet best-written stories of the genre.Gameplay-wise FFVIII is a bit of an odd one out in the series with the large amount of gameplay changes it features. Although a lot could be said about these, the length of a Steam review simply cannot hold this much information, so let’s just say that some of them, like the expanded Limit Breaks, are favourably looked upon and work well; while others, like the junction system, were met with great opposition and never returned in later games. The Steam version can be considered a well enough port of the original PlayStation release, with a bunch of really nice technical features, including better display compatibility and more user-friendly controlling. Sadly, like the Steam version of Final Fantasy VII, it features a subpar version of the original PSX music tracks, the same ones that were used in the original PC version.Overall, the Steam Edition is Final Fantasy VIII may not be the HD remake lot of people still want, but it is a good port of an excellent game, well worth of owning and playing, even if you have the original PSX disc somewhere.

To do so you’ll have to gather friends and allies, explore much of the planet, and of course slowly discover a rich backstory told in two separate timelines, which will eventually (with a little guess work) uncover one of the most confusing, yet best-written stories of the genre.Gameplay-wise FFVIII is a bit of an odd one out in the series with the large amount of gameplay changes it features. Although a lot could be said about these, the length of a Steam review simply cannot hold this much information, so let’s just say that some of them, like the expanded Limit Breaks, are favourably looked upon and work well; while others, like the junction system, were met with great opposition and never returned in later games. The Steam version can be considered a well enough port of the original PlayStation release, with a bunch of really nice technical features, including better display compatibility and more user-friendly controlling. Sadly, like the Steam version of Final Fantasy VII, it features a subpar version of the original PSX music tracks, the same ones that were used in the original PC version.Overall, the Steam Edition is Final Fantasy VIII may not be the HD remake lot of people still want, but it is a good port of an excellent game, well worth of owning and playing, even if you have the original PSX disc somewhere.

												Story – 1/5 -> 20%The story is the typical “defeat the evil mastermind who threatens the life of the entire planet” type of story.  However, it is also incredibly convoluted and filled with many plot holes.  If you finished listening to some NPC's explanation about what is going on and still have no clue who's side they are on, then the story is too convoluted for its own good.  The one redeeming quality is that the main characters are well-defined.  You could easily identify with the main character, Squall.Graphics – 4/5 -> 80%The graphics are much improved over the horrible graphics of the previous game.  Some parts of the game still have rough edges, like a few of the character models, but for the most part, you shouldn't really notice any problems (at least for graphics of its time).  In particular, the FMVs look spectacular and flow smoothly with the rest of the game.Sound – 5/5 -> 100%None of the music or sound effects felt out of place.  Of particular note is the boss theme music which provided an appropriate adrenaline rush.Controls – 9/10 -> 90%Even if you have a problem with the default controls, it is possible to redefine them, and none of the extra ways the main controls were used for “minigames” felt awkward or misused.  The only problem I experienced was that the overworld was incredibly disorienting to navigate without the map open.Resources – 5/5 -> 100%Unlike the Playstation version, this version of FFVIII comes with Chocobo World without the need for a Pocketstation.  This provides an extra source for items beyond the main game.  Even if you choose not to abuse Chocobo World, FFVIII provides plenty of ways to keep your stats in tip-top shape.One interesting resource system in this game is the SeeD rank.  Depending on your rank, you will be paid a certain amount as you walk around the world.  The higher your rank, the more you are paid.  There are a variety of ways to increase your rank, including monster kills and several sidequests.  This ensures you don't have to always face monsters to grind for gold if you don't want to.Player Growth – 3/5 -> 60%FFVIII's unique system is the Junctioning system.  Summon spirits are called Guardian Forces, or GF, which can be linked to particular characters to give them new abilities.  GFs can be taught new abilities for your characters to use as well as slots for particular stats in order to boost them with magic.In addition, enemies level with you, in order to attempt to balance the game.  However, the game is not very well balanced for both newcomers and veterans alike, as leveling up too much tends to make the game more difficult, and it is possible to obtain late game magic spells at the beginning in order to boost your stats ridiculously high.Learnability – 4/5 -> 80%The game regularly provides the option to view a tutorial on various game mechanics.  Unfortunately, it can be rather invasive when you are given a chance later in the game to view a tutorial of a concept you have already been taught.One feature of note is the SeeD Test.  In addition to increasing your SeeD rank, tests also provide a way to test your knowledge of the game mechanics.  The tests can prove to be a nice refresher if you forget anything, since you can view them at any time.Difficulty - 12/15 -> 80%The game initially provides a nice blend of challenging gameplay.  However, it does not provide enough challenging end-game content.  There is a super boss, but it is easy to defeat compared to other Final Fantasy games with super bosses.Entertainment – 38/40 -> 95%While the game is not very challenging overall, the Junction system still makes the gameplay very enjoyable.Replay value – 3/5 -> 60%As with most single player games, there is not much incentive to play the game again, especially if the story hurts your head.  However, the Junction system provides many different ways to approach boss fights.  It can be interesting to experiment with different approaches and create your own challenge runs.Total – 84/100 -> 84%I would recommend at least giving the game a try if you have never played this game before on the Playstation.  It is very fun to experiment with the Junction system and different magic spells.  If you have played the Playstation version and you are a completionist, you might still want to buy the PC version for the inclusion of Chocobo World.

												My personal favorite of all  Final Fantasy  franchises. Played this in 1999 with my brother when I was around 7! If you never played this game, you wouldn't believe how rich the story was, and how wide the range of the conflicts really are. Game is set in the future, but somehow post-apocalyptic after what happened in Centra around 4000 years ago, a Lunar Cry, where in current time people rebuild Centra into what is called a Garden. Relationships in this game are two of the most contributing factors, while others include politics, war, sorcery, and just massive destructions.The game's background arts look ethereally.. poetic. It is just simply stunning. They're all 3D environment, just rendered into 2D and made it into a background where the 3D low-poly (characters) move accross the 3D space that have been motion-tracked to the background. The designs are mostly steampunk (architectural elements of Greek and French) combined with futuristic elements (try to observe the 3D models, colors, sounds, and advanced technology in the game).  Best battle system of all time. Indescribably cool. Junctioning GFs and Magic, draw, limit breaks, elements, statuses, real-time turnbased, weapon forging, student exams, and tons of other stuff. Just get the game and play it. And play its card-game, it's fun as hell.

												People who have been rating this down because of the music don't care about the game. As a matter of fact, if they're letting some sub-standard music get in the way of the game, they probably don't even like the game to begin with and should be disregarded entirely.First of all: the music isn't that bad. It's not bad at all, in fact, and certainly not enough to make people NOT reccomend the game. It has a retro feel to it, which, for any other game, people would be ♥♥♥♥♥♥ing over because #RETROISAWESOMELOL.Second of all: yes, there is a second layer of DRM. Squeenix's login thing. I haven't had issues with my internet in long enough to accurately remember whether or not you actually NEED a constant stable connection, but I seem to recall that with FF7, you could play offline just fine as long as you had an account, which isn't difficult to create (and fake, if you so desire).The game itself remains one of Final Fantasy's most underrated titles. People ♥♥♥♥♥ed about the need to "grind" magic for the "unintuitive" junction system, but how is it any worse than grinding hundreds of millions of XP in any other title? I find the Junction system is laid out very simply and is easy-to-use. But then, I have at least two functioning brain cells to fire neural impulses between, so it wouldn't have taken me much effort to figure out even if I didn't understand it at first.The characters are deep and relatable, to an extent (I mean, how well can you actually relate to a bunch of teenagers who were riased to be elite mercenaries during their childhood). The story is engaging, if somewhat generic, but they genuinely tried to mix it up. The love interest plot developes naturally, though it gets somewhat rushed at one point late in the game when Female Love Interest (tm) goes into a coma and Male Love Interest (tm) who had previously been pushing her away constantly suddenly and abruptly realizes how much he needs her. Overall, it's a very good game. I look forward to when Squeenix releases FF9 for the PC *coughcough*hinthint*cough*getonityoulosers*cough*.

y 1, 2014
												I played this game on the Playstation back when it came out and decided to buy the Steam version for old times' sake. Sorry to say that the PC port of this game is absolutely horrendous. It's not worth the purchase even on a deep discount.The foremost problem is the controls: the button/key labels in-game are indicated using B1, B2, ... B10. Sure, you get shown the button meanings when the game boots, but it's not very useful when you can't remember the key combination for 'escape from battle' (required for the plot in the first game mission) and the in-game comments are useless. Also, don't bother with the controller support for this game. I attempted to use my wired 360 controller and found that the left and right triggers and the directional pad aren't detected -- you can't specify them in the custom configuration screen. (Also, there goes Zell's limit break.) On an aesthetic note, you should probably just mute the game instead of trying to tolerate the lo-fi, MIDI quality music. It's a shame, because the Dollet music mission is one of my favorites. Also, 'Magic Boost'? Seriously? Drawing magic was a HORRENDOUS idea to begin with, but Magic Boost is pretty much game breaking if you use it early on (it gives you 100 of the fire/thunder/blizzard, fira/blizzara/thundara, firaga/blizzaga/thundaga, all the status effect spells, and a few others... but fortunately it doesn't give you 100 of the top-tier spells like ultima, aura, etc) The game wasn't hard, there's no need for this kind of cheat.

												Truly the best Final Fantasy. 7 was great, but my opinion changed after horrible additions to the story, prequels and movies and such: Cloud never changes and stays mopey. 9 was just horrible, the protagonist being a cross between David Bowie, Meg Ryan and a monkey.
